intro: Helianthopsis utcubambensis, commonly known as the Andean sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant produces yellow to orange flowers that are typically arranged in a compact cluster, resembling a small sunflower. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often growing in rocky or mountainous environments. Helianthopsis utcubambensis is adapted to cold climates and is often found in the Andes, where it contributes to the local biodiversity.
